facts.1: July 4th marks the anniversary of the adoption of the Declaration of Independence in 1776.
facts.2: The first celebrations included bonfires, parades, and the firing of cannons and muskets, accompanied by public readings of the Declaration of Independence.
facts.3: It became a federal holiday in 1870 and is often celebrated with fireworks, picnics, and barbecues.

facts.1: Kupala Night is an ancient pagan Slavic holiday associated with the summer solstice.
facts.2: The celebration involves symbolic rituals such as jumping over bonfires and floating wreaths on rivers.
facts.3: In many Slavic countries, it is believed that this night is a magical time when the veil between the physical and spiritual worlds is the thinnest.

facts.1: Rwanda observes Liberation Day on July 4th to commemorate the end of the genocide in 1994.
facts.2: The day is a national holiday in Rwanda, marking the victory of the Rwandan Patriotic Front (RPF).
facts.3: It's a day of remembrance and gratitude for the progress that has been made in rebuilding the nation since the atrocities.
